content.description:
A very sustained crux for endurance lovers. This project traverses the same direction as it's counterpart, "Baby Steps to Greatness," but instead traverses the lower seam versus the upper seam on "Baby Steps." *See picture

Terrible, shallow, and sharp incuts with scrunchy feet and horizontal body movements, this is sure to be an area classic once it cleans up. May be easier for shorter people at times... Shares the same start as "Lubricated, & Baby Steps."
content.location:
Shares the start to "Lubricated, & Baby Steps," but follows the low seam instead of the upper seam on the juggy lip of the boulder.

Once you hit the arete and near the start to "HooHaw," make your way straight up and finish strong (but pumped to hell), topping out at the same place as HooHaw with a sweet and moderate mantle, (if you can avoid the flash pump of course). Crux is a near impossible gaston to crimp that is shallow and insecure.

How low can you go? Endurance test piece and area classic once it cleans up!

content.description: Start on good jugs and work up through obvious sharp crimps to a slopey and technical topout. The crux is topping out and mantling with blind feet. It looks and feels super easy at first glance, but then you try topping it and realize why the grade is what it is. Technical climbing to finish this one. Press hard and pray!
content.location: Obvious residual chalk exists at the far left hand side of the boulder

content.description: A 3 move wonder, this problem may be harder for short people. Start on the obvious arete sidepull jugs and make a few dynamic moves to the upper lip of the boulder and fun mantle top-out, hugging the arete during the entire process. This fun boulder problem starts on the far right side of the boulder and goes straight up the arete. Beautiful line that should clean up nicely and provides gymnastic style movement for people of all sizes and abilities, but shorter people should be ready to jump!
content.location: Far right of boulder on obvious sidepull jug starting holds. Hug the arete.

content.description: A short but difficult crux on poor feet and terrible holds, it lends itself to easier but pumpy climbing to finish. The boulder requires some endurance as it traverses left-to-right on the most beautiful low ball line imaginable. Crux is rather difficult to ponder. Extra points for flashing, it's a puzzle worth solving!
content.location: Starts on obvious jugs just left of "Lubricated Baby Boomers" in the roof. Marked by chalk and rat feces, it traverses left to right past the start of said problem. Shares the same start as "Sex Kitten" and "Lubricated."
